title: 114_hr3284
content: The Act titled "Mary Jo Lawyer Spano Mesothelioma Patient Registry Act of 2015" establishes a patient registry for mesothelioma data collection and research under Title III of the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary will develop a patient registry to collect data on mesothelioma in the United States, including tracking epidemiology, treatment outcomes, and prevalence of the disease. The patient registry for mesothelioma aims to collect data on treatment outcomes, patient longevity, number of patients by hospital, incidence and prevalence in the US, factors associated with the disease, demographic factors, and making non-identifiable information available for research and prevention efforts. The patient registry for mesothelioma collects information on incidence, prevalence, demographics, and other factors associated with the disease to facilitate research and prevention efforts. The patient registry for mesothelioma collects information on demographics, risk factors, diagnosis, and progression markers associated with the disease to aid in research and prevention efforts. It also includes data on the epidemiology, natural history, prevention, detection, management, and treatment approaches for mesothelioma. The Secretary consults with experts on epidemiology, prevention, detection, management, and outcomes measures for mesothelioma, including non-Federal specialists in disease surveillance, patient care, and health information technology. The Secretary consults with experts on mesothelioma research, care, patient service, health information technology, clinicians, and research scientists. Information from the registry will be shared with federal agencies like NIH, FDA, CMS, AHRQ, VA, and DoD. The Secretary will make information from the mesothelioma registry available to the public and ensure stringent privacy protections. Reports to Congress are required within 18 months of the enactment of the Mary Jo Lawyer Spano Mesothelioma Patient Registry Act of 2015. The Secretary must submit reports to Congress within 18 months of the enactment of the Mary Jo Lawyer Spano Mesothelioma Patient Registry Act of 2015, outlining findings, future plans for the registry, and activities to establish partnerships for expansion. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress within 4 years of the enactment of the Mary Jo Lawyer Spano Mesothelioma Patient Registry Act of 2015, detailing the development, information collected, use, and coordination of the mesothelioma patient registry. The report to Congress will detail the development, information collected, use, and coordination of the mesothelioma patient registry, including guidelines for use and coordination of databases.
